data.title: Famous People Born in 1862
data.meta_description: Celebrate the birthdays of 116 famous people, historical figures and celebrities born in 1862 like O. Henry, Claude Debussy and Gerhart Hauptmann.
data.text:
Sir Matthew Nathan, British Governor of Queensland and other places (d. 1939)

Frank Nelson Doubleday, American publisher (founder of Doubleday & Co), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1934)

Walter Travis, Australian-American golfer, writer, course designer (US Amateur C'ship 1900-01, 03; British Amateur 1904), born in Maldon, Australia (d. 1927)

John Evert Akkeringa, Dutch painter and etcher (d. 1942)

David Hilbert, German mathematician (Hilbert spaces, invariant theory, axiomatization of geometry), born in Königsberg, East Prussia (d. 1943)

Edith Wharton

American Pulitzer prize-winning novelist (Ethan Frome, House of Mirth), born in New York City

Frederick Delius, British composer (A Mass of Life; Brigg Fair; In a Summer Garden), born in Bradford, England (d. 1934)

Walter Damrosch, German-American conductor (New York Symphony, 1885-1928; commissioned Gershwin's Piano Concerto), and composer (The Man Without A Country), born in Breslau, Silesia (d. 1950) [1]

Felipe Villanueva y Gutierrez, Mexican composer and violinist of the Porfiriato period, born in Tecámac, Mexico (d. 1893)

Bernard Maybeck, American architect (Palace of Fine Arts, San Francisco), born in New York City (d. 1957)

Karel Weis, Czech composer and folk song collector, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1944)

Edward German (Jones), English composer (Merrie England), born in Whitchurch, Shropshire, England (d. 1936)

Feb 17 Mori Ōgai, Japanese novelist and poet (d. 1922)

Karen Hulda Garborg, Norwegian playwright (Mot Solen/Eli), born near Hamar, Norway (d. 1934)

Anastasios Metaxas, Greek architect (restored Panathinaiko Stadium 1896 Olympics Athens) and shooter (Olympic bronze trap, single shot 1908), born in Athens, Greece (d. 1937)

Boris Borisovich Galitzine, Russian physicist (d. 1916)

Mar 2 John Jay Chapman, American poet, and writer (Learning & Other Essays), born in New York City (d. 1933)

Robert Emden, Swiss astronomer and physicist (book on Gas Spheres), born in St. Gallen, Switzerland (d. 1940)

Siegbert Tarrasch, German chess player (d. 1934)

Joseph Lee, Father of Playgrounds movement, born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1937)

Jane Delano, American nurse and educator (Red Cross Nursing Service during WWI), born in Montour Falls, New York (d. 1919)

Vasiliy Metallov, Russian composer and musical historian, born in Saratov, Russian Empire (d. 1926)

Eva Thatcher, American actress, born in Omaha, Nebraska (d. 1942)

Mar 14 Vilhelm Bjerknes, Norwegian-American physicist and meteorologist, born in Christiania, Norway (d. 1951)

Silvio Gesell, Belgian economist (d. 1930)

Nathaniel Reed, American outlaw turned evangelist (d. 1950)

Aristide Briand

11 time Prime Minister of France (1909-22) and 1926 Nobel Peace Prize winner, born in Nantes, France

George William Louis Marshall-Hall, English composer, born in London (d. 1915)

Nicholas Murray Butler, American philosopher, diplomat (Nobel Peace Prize 1931), educator (Columbia University President), born in Elizabeth, New Jersey (d. 1947)

Louis Ganne, French composer, born in Buxières-les-Mines (d. 1923)

Charles Evans Hughes, American statesman, Republican politician and 11th Chief Justice of Supreme Court (1930-41), born in Glens Falls, New York (d. 1948)

Apr 11 William Wallace Campbell, American astronomer and Director of Lick Observatory, born in Hancock County, Ohio (d. 1938)

Pyotr Stolypin, 3rd Prime Minister of Russia (1906-11), born in Dresden, Kingdom of Saxony (d. 1911)

Edward Grey

British Liberal statesman and Minister of Foreign Affairs (1905-16), born in London

Vittorio Mario Vanzo, Italian composer, born in Padua, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1945)

Jack Sheridan, American Baseball Hall of Fame umpire (World Series 1905, 07-08, 10), born in Decatur, Illinois (d. 1914)

Maurice Emmanuel, French composer and musicologist (Salamine), born in Bar-sur-Aube, France (d. 1938)

Max Elskamp, Belgian author and poet (Lesson Joies Blondes, Maya), born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1931)

Arthur Schnitzler, Austrian playwright (La Ronde - Reigen), and novelist (Fräulein Else), born in Leopoldstadt, Vienna, Austrian Empire (d. 1931)

May 15 John Reeves Ellerman, British accountant, businessman, and shipping magnate, born in Kingston upon Hull, England (d. 1933)

Albert von Schrenk-Notzing, German psychologist who studied the paranormal (d. 1929)

Mikhail Nesterov, Russian painter (d. 1942)

August Cuppens, Flemish author (Limburgs Driemanschap), born in Beringen, Belgium (d. 1924)

William "Dummy" Hoy, American baseball outfielder (most accomplished deaf player in MLB history; NL stolen base leader 1888; Washington Senators, Cincinnati Reds), born in Houcktown, Ohio (d. 1961)

Henry Slocum, American tennis player (US Nationals 1888-89), born in Syracuse, New York (d. 1949)

António Feijó, Portuguese poet and diplomat, born in Ponte de Lima, Portugal (d. 1917)

Allvar Gullstrand, Swedish physician (Nobel 1911), born in Landskrona, Sweden (d. 1930)

Henry John Newbolt, English poet and author (Studies Green & Gray), born in Bilston, Staffordshire, England (d. 1938)

Philipp Lenard, Austrian physicist (Nobel 1905), born in Pozsony, Austria-Hungary (d. 1947)

Mrs. Leslie Carter, American actress and writer (Rocky Mountain Mystery, The Heart of Maryland), born in Lexington, Kentucky (d. 1937)

Damrong Rajanubhab, Thai prince, son of King Mongkut and brother of King Chulalongkorn and historian, born in Bangkok, Thailand (d. 1943)

Jun 21 Henry Holden Huss, American classical pianist, composer, and educator, born in Newark, New Jersey (d. 1953)

Jun 21 Johannes Schlaf, German writer and translator, born in Querfurt, Germany (d. 1941)

Vasily Georgiyevich Wrangell, Russian composer, born in St. Petersburg, Russia (d. 1901)

May Irwin, Canadian comedienne and singer ("Hot Time in the Old Town"), born in Whitby, Ontario (d. 1938)

William Henry Bragg, English physicist (Nobel Prize for Physics, 1915 - crystalline structure analysis by means of X-rays), born in Westward, Cumberland, England (d. 1942) [1]

Friedrich Ernst Koch, German composer, born in Berlin, Kingdom of Prussia (d. 1927)

Liza Lehmann, English composer, born in London, England (d. 1918)

Florence Bascom, American geologist and 1st woman hired by the US Geological Survey, born in Williamstown, Massachusetts (d. 1945)

Jul 14 Gustav Klimt, Austrian Symbolist painter (The Kiss), born in Baumgarten, Austria-Hungary (d. 1918)

Ida B. Wells (-Barnett), American journalist, civil rights activist, and co-founder of the NAACP, born in Holly Springs, Mississippi (d. 1931)

Nikolai Nikolayevich Yudenich, Russian WWI general, born in Moscow, Russian Empire (d. 1933)

Jul 18 Victor, Prince Napoléon (Napoléon V), French pretender to throne, born in Palais-Royal, Paris (d. 1926)

Steve Fairbairn, British rower and coach (Jesus College Boat Club, Cambridge University), born in Geelong, Victoria, Australia (d. 1938)

M. R. James, English scholar and author (Ghost Stories of an Antiquary), born in Goodnestone, Dover, Kent (d. 1936)

Joseph Merrick, "The Elephant Man", born in Leicester, England (d. 1890)

Victoria of Baden, Queen of Sweden, born in Karlsruhe, Baden (d. 1931)

Carrie Jacobs-Bond, American singer, pianist, songwriter ("I Love You Truly"; "A Perfect Day"), born in Janesville, Wisconsin (d. 1946)

Amos Alonzo Stagg, American athlete and American football pioneer, born in West Orange, New Jersey (d. 1965)

Claude Debussy

French composer (La Mer; Clair de lune), born in Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France

Herbert Booth, American son of William and Catherine Booth (d. 1926)

Andrew Fisher

5th Prime Minister of Australia (1908-09, 1910-13, 1914-15), born in Crosshouse, Ayrshire, Scotland

Maurice Maeterlinck

Belgian playwright, poet and author (Blue Bird, Nobel 1911), born in Ghent, Belgium

Adolphe Appia, Swiss set designer and theorist (Wagner Opera sets), born in Geneva, Switzerland (d. 1928)

Alphons Diepenbrock, Dutch composer, conductor, and essayist, born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1936)

Sep 2 Franjo Krežma, Croatian violinist, born in Osijek, Croatia (d. 1881)

Hawley Harvey Crippen [Dr Crippen], American homeopath and first killer to be caught with the aid of wireless telegraphy, born in Coldwater, Michigan (d. 1910)

Sep 11 Julian Byng, 1st Viscount Byng of Vimy, British army officer, born in Wrotham Park, Hertfordshire, England (d. 1935)

O. Henry

American short story writer (Cabbages and Kings), born in Greensboro, North Carolina

Dirk Bos, Dutch Liberal 2nd Member of Parliament, born in Groningen, Netherlands (d. 1916)

Adeline De Walt Reynolds, American actress (Son of Dracula), born in Benton County, Iowa (d. 1961)

James E. Talmage, English religious leader (LDS Church apostle), born in Hungerford, Berkshire, England (d. 1933)

Sep 21 Johan Castberg, Norwegian politician (Castbergian Child Laws protecting extra-martial children), born in Brevik, Norway (d. 1926)

Billy Hughes, 7th Prime Minister of Australia (Labor, Nationalist: 1915-23), born in London (d. 1952)

Sep 25 Léon Boëllmann, French organist and composer (Variations Symphoniques; Suite Gothique), born in Ensisheim, Alsace, France (d. 1897)

Louis Botha

Boer general and statesman, 1st Prime Minister of South Africa (1910-19), born in Greytown, Natal

Georgy Eduardovich Konyus (Conus), Russian composer, and music theorist, born in Moscow, Russia (d. 1933)

Johnny Briggs, English cricket all-rounder (33 Tests; 118 wickets @ 17.75), born in Sutton-in-Ashfield, Nottinghamshire (d. 1902)

Edward Stratemeyer, American author (The Rover Boys), born in Elizabeth, New Jersey (d. 1930)

Albert J. Beveridge, American politician and historian (Progressive leader, Senator Indiana 1899-1911), born in Highland County, Ohio (d. 1927)

Arthur De Greef, Belgian composer, born in Louvain, Belgium (d. 1940)

Mary Kingsley, English ethnographer and explorer who became the first European to enter parts of Gabon, Africa, born in London (d. 1900)

Auguste Lumière, French engineer and filmmaker who made the 1st movie (Workers Leaving Lumière Factory), born in Besançon, France (d. 1954)

Johan Wagenaar, Dutch composer (Cyrano de Bergerac), born in Utrecht, Netherlands (d. 1941)

Eden Phillpotts, English novelist, poet and playwright (Red Madymaynes), born in Mount Abu, Rajasthan, India (d. 1960)

James Edward Sullivan, American sports official and founder (Amateur Athletic Union), born in New York City (d. 1914)

Adolf Bartels, German journalist and poet, born in Wesselburen, Holstein, Germany (d. 1945)

Gerhart Hauptmann

German author (Before Dawn - Nobel 1912), born in Obersalzbrunn, Silesia, Prussia

Charles Turner, Australian cricket fast bowler (17 Tests; 101 wickets @ 16.53; fastest to 50 Test wickets; NSWCA), born in Bathurst, Australia (d. 1944)

Billy Sunday, American evangelist (revivals and sermons reflected the emotional upheavals caused by transition from rural to industrial society in the United States), born in Story County, Iowa (d. 1935)

Willem Vliegen, Dutch journalist and chairman (SDAP), born in Gulpen, Netherlands (d. 1947)

Alberto Williams, Argentine pianist and composer (Etrerno Reposo), born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1952)

Nov 23 Theo van Rysselberghe, Belgian painter (pointillism), born in Ghent, Belgium (d. 1926)

Ethelbert Nevin, American pianist and composer (The Rosary; Narcissus), born in Edgeworth, Pennsylvania (d. 1901) [1]

Marc Aurel Stein, Hungarian-British archaeologist, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1943)

Friedrich Klose, German-Swiss composer (König Elf), born in Karlsruhe, Germany (d. 1942)

Jules Renkin, Belgian politician (28th Prime Minister of Belgium 1931-32), born in Ixelles, Belgium (d. 1934)

Paul Adam, French writer (La Bataille d'Uhde), born in Paris, France (d. 1920)

Georges Feydeau, French playwright (La Dame de Chez Maxim's), born in Paris (d. 1921)

Karel Kovařovic, Czech harpist, conductor (Prague National Theatre, 1900-20), and composer (The Dogheads), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1920)

John M. Acket, Dutch literary (Grammatic Conceptions) (d. 1933)

Jack 'The Nonpareil' Dempsey, Irish boxer (first holder of World Middleweight Championship 1886-90), born in Curran, County Kildare (d. 1895)

Eugene Demolder, Belgian writer (Sous la robe), born in Sint-Jans-Molenbeek, Belgium (d. 1919)

Connie Mack

American Baseball Hall of Fame catcher, manager and owner (World Series 1910, 11, 13, 29, 30; most managerial wins, losses and games managed in MLB history; Philadelphia A's), born in East Brookfield, Massachusetts

Henri Pirenne, Belgian historian (History of Belgium) (d. 1935)

Alexander Amfiteatrov, Russian-Italian journalist, newspaper editor, novelist, and historian, born in Kaluga, Russia (d. 1923)
